Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Plasma Etching System for Multidisciplinary Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Non-Technical: Youngstown State University (YSU) and its industrial partners are aggressively pursuing research in various materials including semiconductors, polymers, carbon nanotubes, ceramic-metallic composites and functional materials. A major requirement in processing these materials is the ability to etch desired patterns for devices. Funds from the Major Research Instrumentation program provide support for acquisition of an inductively-coupled plasma etching instrument. This instrument enables advances in fabricating efficient devices and helps to educate and train K-12, undergraduate & graduate students and high school science teachers. With the launch of YSU's new PhD program in Materials Science & Engineering, this instrument provides a pivotal training and research tool for use in at least 10 current research projects and provides training to over 30 PhD and MS graduate students and postdocs, and more than 300 undergraduate students per year as it is fully integrated into undergraduate and graduate curriculum at YSU. The PI and co-PIs actively participate in various outreach and minority-oriented programs such as the Youngstown Area Physics Alliance, Summer STEM for Minority Students and Project SEED which provide a platform for recruiting students from underrepresented groups to the research activities enabled by this instrument.


Technical: The multi-disciplinary materials-related research activities at YSU and its industrial partners include wide-bandgap semiconductors for high power electronic and short wavelength optoelectronic devices, multilayered polymeric systems for various photonic applications, carbon nanotubes for chemical and biological sensor applications, ceramic-metallic composites for military combat applications, and functional materials for micro-electro-mechanical systems. High density plasma etching offers a vital capability for fabricating the relevant functional device designs. The goal of this acquisition of the inductively-coupled plasma etching system is to support multidisciplinary research and education at YSU. Together with the existing state-of-the-art electron microscopy and lithography tools recently acquired at YSU, this equipment enables better understanding of the underlying structures of these materials in order to develop optoelectronic and nano/micro scale devices as well as elucidate the basic scientific processes governing the interaction of photons and charge carriers with nanometer size structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation project enabled Youngstown State University (YSU) and its industrial partners to acquire the plasma etching system to fulfill two main objectives:

(a)    Advance their research in various materials including semiconductors, polymers, carbon nanotubes, ceramic-metallic composites and functional materials. This is a key instrument needed in fabricating electronic and photonic devices.

(b)   Help recruit, educate and train K-12, undergraduate & graduate students.

 During the three year duration of the project, the PI, co-PIs and students working with them accomplished the above objectives as follows:

 

(A) Fabrication of Ti Schottky Barrier Diodes

We have been studying the properties of Schottky barrier diodes fabricated with Ti Schottky contacts. These contacts were deposited at various substrate temperatures from ~20 oC to 900 oC and annealed at 500 oC for 60 hours. A manuscript with the results from this work was submitted for publication to Journal of Applied Physics. Additional information was requested from the review of this manuscript. The Plasma Etching System was used to perform isolation etching needed especially on samples with contacts deposited on heated substrates. Wet etching was not effective in removing the unwanted Ti after high temperature deposition. The results from this work showed that diodes with Ti contacts deposited at 200 oC performed the best, with high barrier height, low ideality factor and low reverse leakage current. The x-ray diffraction scans of these samples indicated the presence of TiC (111) with peaks at 35.4o, SiC (004) with peaks at 35.6o, Ti5Si3 (210) with peaks at 38o, Ti3SiC2 (008) with peaks at ~ 40o and Ti5Si3 (002) with peaks at 42o. The work functions of TiC (4.6 eV) is higher than that of Ti (4.33 eV) and Ti5Si3 (4.2 eV). Furthermore, it was found that the work function of TiC varies with deposition temperature, decreasing from 5.2 eV at 250 oC to about 4.5 eV at 550 oC. The optimum results obtained for the contacts deposited at 200 oC possible came about due to formation of TiC a larger work function. The submitted manuscript reporting this work has now been transferred from Journal of Applied Physics to AIP Advances (September 2017).

(B)  Fabrication of 3-D Photonic Crystals

We have been working on fabricating 3-dimensional photonic crystals (PC) based on layered oxide materials. 17 bilayers of SiO2(300 nm)/ZnO(300nm) were deposited on sapphire substrate. This already forms a 1-dimensional (PC) because of the refractive index difference of the two oxides. To produce 3-D photonic crystals requires making a nano pillar array on this oxide film. Using electron beam lithography and dry etching, we fabricated these nano pillar arrays in various triangular lattices.  The largest etch depth we have obtained from the etching so far is 1.2 micrometers, which is about half way to our goal of 3 micrometers. We are presently performing optical characterization of the arrays so far fabricated.

(C) Student Training

During the three year period of this project, the plasma etching system provided opportunity where several students received training and education in advanced device processing techniques:

(a)    Students in the PI’s research program: 3 High School students (through Project SEED), 7 undergraduate students, 3 MS students. One student, Krishna Kundeti was accepted for an intership experience in Summer 2016 with Delphi company and he completed a masters degree in May 2017. He expects to return to YSU in the Spring for a PhD in materials science and engineering program at YSU and possibly work with the PI. Another student, Mr. Sundar Babu Isukapati, was accepted for a 6-month internship in a major semiconductor company (ON-Semiconductor). The experience from this project helped these students secure the internship positions they got. The project also helped recruit students to YSU, some of the students came from outside the USA and others from nearby Universities who transferred to YSU.

 (b)   Students in the course taught by the PI (Physics 5830 and Physics 6930). The PI is currently teaching this course and the students enrolled in it comprise 3 PhD students, 2 MS students and 2 senior undergraduate students. The number of graduate student has been increasing in recent years since the acquisition of the plasma etching system (2 in 2014, 4 in 2016 and 5 in 2017). This course is structured with 2/3 lectures and 1/3 laboratory hands-on activities. Plasma etching is one of the activities the students are required to do. Each student is then given a project to complete, involving fabrication and characterization of a device structure.
